prompt: Explain how an aerospace engineer determines the correct trajectory for a communication satellite. Discuss orbital mechanics principles, required calculations, the importance of simplifications/assumptions, and how data is validated and visualized.

criteria.name: Understanding of Orbital Mechanics
criteria.description: Demonstrates knowledge of orbital motion, Kepler’s laws, and circular/elliptical orbits.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Clearly explains orbital principles with examples (e.g., LEO, GEO).
performance_descriptors.good: Explains main orbital concepts with some application.
performance_descriptors.average: Mentions basic orbital motion without depth.
performance_descriptors.needs_improvement: Unclear or incorrect explanation of orbital motion.
performance_descriptors.poor: Fails to demonstrate understanding of orbital principles.

criteria.name: Trajectory Calculation and Assumptions
criteria.description: Uses relevant formulas (e.g., velocity, time period) and discusses assumptions.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Applies formulas with assumptions clearly justified and appropriate for context.
performance_descriptors.good: Correct formulas used with basic assumptions.

criteria.name: Validation and Visualization
criteria.description: Explains how results are checked and presents visual output like orbits/graphs.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Validation through simulation and visuals (e.g., orbital paths).
performance_descriptors.good: Mentions testing or shows visuals without much detail.
performance_descriptors.average: Limited validation or rough visuals included.
performance_descriptors.poor: No attempt to validate or visualize data.

criteria.name: Technical Reporting and Structure
criteria.description: Organizes content logically and uses formal aerospace language.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Highly structured, technically accurate with formal tone.
performance_descriptors.good: Mostly structured with appropriate technical terms.

llm_questions: What formulas are used to compute orbital period and velocity?
What assumptions are made when calculating trajectories?
How do engineers validate satellite orbits?
What tools are used to visualize orbital paths?
llm_answers: Kepler’s laws and Newton’s law of gravitation govern satellite motion.
T = 2π√(r³/GM) for period and v = √(GM/r) for orbital speed.
Assumptions may include perfect vacuum, spherical Earth, and no perturbations.
Validation is done via simulation and tracking from Earth stations.
STK, MATLAB, and Python tools like poliastro are used for visualization.
